stem: Choose the correct verb: He ___ soccer on Sundays.
rationale: Present simple for habits with third person singular -s.

stem: They ___ dinner now.
rationale: Now is a marker for present continuous.

stem: Yesterday, Mina ___ to the park.
rationale: Past simple with yesterday, irregular go→went.

stem: Change to past: We visit the museum.
Have you ___ sushi?
rationale: Present perfect uses have + past participle, ever before the verb.

stem: Choose the correct sentence.
options: He has lived here for five years.
He has lived here since five years.
He lived here since five years.
He has been living here since five years.
answer: He has lived here for five years.
rationale: Use for + period, since + point in time.

stem: Look at those clouds. It ___ soon.
rationale: Be going to for prediction based on evidence.

stem: When I arrived, he ___.
rationale: Earlier past action uses past perfect.

stem: By the time we reached the station, the train ___.
rationale: By the time + past simple → earlier past is past perfect.

stem: Which sentence uses since 2019 correctly?
rationale: Since + point in time with present perfect.

stem: By next July, she ___ the course.
rationale: Future perfect for completion before a future point.

stem: While I ___, my phone rang.
rationale: Ongoing action in the past uses past continuous.

stem: Choose the correct sentence.
options: She has been studying English since March.
She has studied English for March.
She is studying English for March.
answer: She has been studying English since March.
rationale: Since + point with present perfect continuous.

stem: He ___ for two hours before the meeting started.
rationale: Earlier ongoing action uses past perfect continuous.

stem: If you call me at 8 p.m., I ___ dinner.
rationale: Future continuous for an action in progress at a specific future time.

stem: Use the present simple for a timetable.
options: The plane leaves at 9 a.m. tomorrow.
The plane is leave at 9 a.m. tomorrow.
The plane will leaves at 9 a.m. tomorrow.
The plane leave at 9 a.m. tomorrow.
answer: The plane leaves at 9 a.m. tomorrow.

stem: Correct the sequence of tenses.
options: He said he was tired yesterday.
He says he was tired yesterday.
He said he has been tired yesterday.
He said he is tired yesterday.
answer: He said he was tired yesterday.
rationale: Backshift after a past reporting verb.

stem: This time next year, I ___ at university.
rationale: Future continuous for an action in progress at a future time.

stem: It ___ raining for three hours.
rationale: Present perfect continuous for duration up to now.

stem: By the time the semester ended, I ___ my thesis.
rationale: Earlier completed action uses past perfect.

stem: Choose can or can't: I ___ swim.
Which is the most polite request?
You ___ see a doctor.
Rewrite using have to: Tom must wear a helmet at work.
options: Tom has to wear a helmet at work.
Tom have to wear a helmet at work.
Tom must to wear a helmet at work.
Tom has wear a helmet at work.
answer: Tom has to wear a helmet at work.
rationale: Obligation can be paraphrased with have to.

stem: It ___ rain later, so take an umbrella.
Which is correct?
options: He can to play the piano.
He is can play the piano.
rationale: After a modal, use the base form.

stem: You ___ eat too much sugar.
Rewrite using was able to: When I was five, I could swim.
options: When I was five, I was able to swim.
When I was five, I am able to swim.
When I was five, I was able swim.
When I was five, I could to swim.
answer: When I was five, I was able to swim.
rationale: Past general ability can use was able to.

stem: The lights are off and the car is gone. They ___ be at home.
Which sentence gives advice with should about study habits?
options: You should review your notes every day.
You should to review your notes every day.
You must review your notes every day.
You can reviewing your notes every day.
answer: You should review your notes every day.

stem: Use should have p.p. to criticize the past: You didn't call me.
rationale: Past criticism uses should have + p.p.

stem: The train ___ arrive by 6 p.m. if there is no delay.
Improve the request: May you help me?
rationale: Polite request uses could you + base verb.

stem: We smell thick smoke. There ___ be a fire nearby.
rationale: Strong evidence triggers must for deduction.

stem: He looks exhausted. He ___ have been working all night.
rationale: Strong past deduction uses must have + been V-ing.

stem: Rewrite to a weaker possibility: It must be true.
Choose the correct sentence.
options: Students must to submit the form.
Students have to to submit the form.
rationale: No to after a modal, use base verb.

stem: In formal rules, which modal shows permission? Students ___ submit forms by email.
rationale: Formal permission is expressed with may.

stem: If you want to pass, you ___ to work harder.
rationale: Have to + base verb expresses necessity, must to is ungrammatical.

stem: Rewrite with ought to to express moral advice: You should respect the deadline.
options: You ought to respect the deadline.
You should to respect the deadline.
answer: You ought to respect the deadline.
rationale: Ought to + base verb for moral advice.

stem: Choose the correct passive form: The cake ___ by Mom every Sunday.
rationale: Present simple passive uses be + past participle for habits.

stem: The house ___ now.
rationale: Action happening now uses present progressive passive.

stem: Yesterday, the window ___ by a strong wind.
rationale: Past event takes past simple passive was + pp.

stem: Last year, many trees ___ for the new park.
rationale: Past simple passive of a regular verb.

stem: The report ___ already.
rationale: Present perfect passive has been + pp with already.

stem: English ___ in many countries.
rationale: Generic truth uses present simple passive.

stem: Exam rules say phones ___ during tests.
rationale: Modal passive uses modal + be + pp.

stem: Everyone praised the team. Choose the correct passive.
options: The team was praised by everyone.
Everyone was praised by the team.
The team is praising by everyone.
answer: The team was praised by everyone.
rationale: Object becomes subject, be + pp, by-phrase optional.

stem: They gave him a prize. Choose the best passive.
options: He was given to a prize.

stem: He ___ by a car yesterday.
At the moment, the bridge ___.
rationale: Ongoing action now uses be being + pp.

stem: Choose the sentence showing a state, not an action.
options: The shop is closed by the owner now.
The owner is closing the shop now.
The owner closed the shop yesterday.
rationale: Adjectival passive shows a state with no action focus.

stem: People laughed at the idea. Choose the correct passive.
rationale: Prepositional passive keeps the particle after the verb.

stem: They are building a new road near the river. Choose the passive.
options: A new road is being built near the river.
A new road has being built near the river.
A new road is built near the river now.
A new road was being built near the river every day.
answer: A new road is being built near the river.
rationale: Present progressive passive for ongoing construction.

stem: They made me clean the room. Choose the passive.
options: I was made to clean the room.
I was made clean the room.
I made to clean the room.
I am made cleaning the room.
answer: I was made to clean the room.

stem: People say that the actor is ill. Choose the passive.
options: The actor is said to be ill.
The actor said to be ill.
The actor is saying to be ill.
It says the actor to be ill.
answer: The actor is said to be ill.
rationale: Reporting verb passive uses be said to + base form.

stem: Someone has stolen my wallet. Choose the passive.
options: My wallet is stolen by someone now.
rationale: Present perfect passive has been + pp for recent result.

stem: We have to handle this issue today. Choose the passive.
options: This issue has to be handled today.
This issue to be handled today.
answer: This issue has to be handled today.
rationale: Have to be + pp for necessity in passive.

stem: Everyone looked up to the manager. Choose the passive.
options: The manager was looked up to by everyone.
The manager was looked to up by everyone.
The manager was looked up by everyone.
The manager looked up to by everyone.
answer: The manager was looked up to by everyone.
rationale: Phrasal prepositional verb keeps particle order in passive.

stem: They will have finished the report by Friday. Choose the passive.
options: The report will have been finished by Friday.
The report will be finished by Friday by them have.
The report had been finished by Friday.
The report will have finished by Friday.
answer: The report will have been finished by Friday.
rationale: Future perfect passive will have been + pp.

stem: If you heat ice, it ___.
rationale: Zero conditional uses present simple in both clauses.

stem: If it rains, we ___ at home.
rationale: First conditional uses will in the main clause.

stem: Unless you hurry, you ___ the bus.
rationale: Unless means if not, first conditional pattern.

stem: If I ___ time, I will help you.
rationale: If-clause takes present simple with future result.

stem: If I ___ rich, I would travel the world.
rationale: Second conditional uses past simple, be → were in formal use.

stem: If I were you, I ___ harder.
rationale: Advice pattern uses would + base verb.

stem: I wish I ___ taller.
rationale: Wish about the present uses past form, be → were.

stem: I wish I ___ harder last year.
rationale: Wish about the past uses past perfect.

stem: If you finish early, you ___ go home.
rationale: Modal outcome within first conditional is acceptable.

stem: As long as you ___ quiet, you can stay.
rationale: As long as + present simple for conditions.

stem: If he ___ the alarm, he would have left earlier.
rationale: Third conditional uses past perfect in the if-clause.

stem: If I ___ more careful then, I wouldn't be in this mess now.
rationale: Mixed conditional with past cause and present result.

stem: If only I ___ more time!
rationale: If only + past for present wish.

stem: Had I known the truth, I ___ you.
rationale: Inversion of the third conditional omits if.

stem: The teacher demands that he ___ on time.
rationale: Mandative subjunctive uses base form be.

stem: Choose the correct conditional inversion.
options: Should you need any help, call me.
If should you need any help, call me.
Should you will need any help, call me.
If you should needing any help, call me.
answer: Should you need any help, call me.
rationale: Should + subject + base verb forms an inverted first conditional.

stem: Were it not for your help, I ___ failed.
rationale: Were it not for = If it were not for, past result uses would have + pp.

stem: Provided that you ___ the form, you can attend.
rationale: Provided that takes present simple for a real condition.

stem: But for the heavy traffic, we ___ on time.
rationale: But for + noun = If it had not been for, past result uses would have + pp.

stem: Choose the correct mixed conditional for a past cause with a present result.
options: If she had been more patient, she would still have the job.
If she has been more patient, she would still have the job.
If she were more patient, she would still had the job.
If she had been more patient, she will still have the job.
answer: If she had been more patient, she would still have the job.
rationale: Past perfect in if-clause with would + base verb for present result.

stem: Choose the correct word: The girl ___ lives next door is my friend.
rationale: 사람을 수식하는 주격 관계대명사는 who가 적절하다.

stem: Choose the correct word: The book ___ is on the desk is mine.
I met the man about ___ you talked.
rationale: 전치사 바로 뒤에는 격이 드러나는 whom이 온다, about whom.

stem: This is the student ___ mother is a doctor.
This is the cafe ___ we first met.
Choose the correct relative adverb: The reason ___ I was late was heavy traffic.
Choose the correct non-defining clause.
options: My uncle, who is a pilot, travels a lot.
My uncle who is a pilot travels a lot,
My uncle, that is a pilot, travels a lot.
My uncle which is a pilot travels a lot.
answer: My uncle, who is a pilot, travels a lot.
rationale: 비제한적 용법은 콤마와 who를 사용하고 that은 불가하다.

stem: Choose the correct non-defining clause.
options: The museum, which was founded in 1890, is famous.
The museum that was founded in 1890, is famous.
The museum which was founded in 1890 is famous,
The museum, that was founded in 1890, is famous.
answer: The museum, which was founded in 1890, is famous.
rationale: 비제한적 용법에는 which와 콤마를 쓰며 that은 쓰지 않는다.

stem: The woman to ___ I spoke was very kind.
rationale: 전치사 앞에서는 whom이 표준이다, to whom.

stem: Choose the correct sentence about 'the way'.
options: That's the way she solved the problem.
That's the way how she solved the problem.
That's the way which she solved the problem.
That's the way where she solved the problem.
answer: That's the way she solved the problem.
rationale: 'the way' 뒤에는 how와 동시 사용 불가, 전치사나 관계대명사 불필요.

stem: Which sentence correctly omits the object relative pronoun?
options: I like the song you recommended.
I like the song that you recommended.
I like the song which you recommended.
I like the song whom you recommended.
answer: I like the song you recommended.

stem: In formal writing, choose the best option: The city ___ I was born has changed a lot.
Choose the correct non-defining relative clause.
options: Seoul, which is the capital, is big.
Seoul that is the capital, is big.
Seoul which is the capital is big.
Seoul, that is the capital, is big.
answer: Seoul, which is the capital, is big.
rationale: 고유명사에 대한 보충설명은 비제한적, which와 콤마 사용.

stem: Choose the reduced relative clause.
options: The man standing near the gate is my uncle.
The man who standing near the gate is my uncle.
The man stand near the gate is my uncle.
The man who is stand near the gate is my uncle.
answer: The man standing near the gate is my uncle.
rationale: 능동 현재분사로 관계절을 축약할 수 있다.

stem: Choose the reduced passive relative clause.
options: Students affected by the new policy must register online.
Students affect by the new policy must register online.
Students which affecting by the new policy must register online.
Students who affected by the new policy must register online.
answer: Students affected by the new policy must register online.
rationale: 수동 의미는 과거분사로 축약한다, who are affected → affected.

stem: She has three sons, two ___ are doctors.
rationale: 부분 표현은 of whom, of which 구조를 쓴다. 사람에는 of whom.

stem: He missed the last train, ___ meant he had to walk home.
rationale: 앞 문장 전체를 받는 것은 비제한적 which다.

stem: The company ___ profits rose 20% announced a bonus.
The circumstances ___ we met were unusual.
Choose the correct phrase: Explain the extent ___ technology affects learning.
I went to the store ___ buy milk.
rationale: 목적은 to 부정사를 쓴다, to buy.

stem: I want ___ a doctor.
rationale: 조동사 want 뒤 명사적 용법 to+동사원형.

stem: We plan ___ a picnic this weekend.
She promised ___ me later.
It is too cold ___ outside.
He is tall enough ___ the shelf.
In order ___ save time, we left early.
rationale: in order to + 동사원형으로 목적 표현.

stem: My teacher told us ___ quietly.
It is easy ___ this app.
rationale: It + be + 형용사 + to V 구조.

stem: Be ready ___ questions at the interview.
rationale: be ready to V, 형용사 보어 뒤 to 부정사.

stem: It is important for students ___ regularly.
She is likely ___ the prize.
We were about ___ when it started to rain.
rationale: be about to V는 임박한 미래.

stem: He opened the door, only ___ nobody was there.
rationale: only to V는 예상 밖의 결과를 나타낸다.

stem: She studied hard so as ___ the test.
rationale: so as to V로 목적을 표현.

stem: This puzzle is difficult ___.
rationale: 가주어 이동 구조, 목적어 제약을 to V로 표현.

stem: The first student ___ the answer will get a prize.
rationale: 서수, 최상급 뒤 수식은 to 부정사.

stem: You are to ___ the rules at all times.
rationale: be to V 구조에서는 동사원형이 온다.

stem: He refused ___ the contract.
It was careless of him ___ the door unlocked.
rationale: It is/was + 형용사(of 사람) + to V 패턴.

stem: Choose the correct form: I enjoy ___ soccer.
rationale: Use a gerund(동명사) after "enjoy" as the object(목적어).

stem: Choose the correct word: ___ is fun.
rationale: A gerund(동명사) can be the subject(주어).

stem: Choose the correct form: He is good at ___ .
rationale: After a preposition(전치사) use a gerund(동명사).

stem: Choose the correct form: We finished ___ our homework.
Choose the correct form: She avoided ___ near traffic.
rationale: Verbs like "avoid" take a gerund(동명사) object(목적어).

stem: Choose the correct form: He kept ___ until noon.
rationale: "Keep" is followed by a gerund(동명사) to show continuation(계속).

stem: Choose the correct form: I look forward to ___ you.
rationale: "To" here is a preposition(전치사) in "look forward to", so use a gerund(동명사).

stem: Choose the correct form: Before ___ to bed, brush your teeth.
rationale: After time prepositions(시간 전치사) like "before", use a gerund(동명사).

stem: Choose the correct form: Stop ___ video games and do your homework.
rationale: "Stop" + gerund(동명사) means stop the activity(활동 중단).

features.contrast: stop V-ing vs stop to V

stem: Choose the correct form: I remember ___ the door last night.
rationale: Gerund(동명사) shows a past memory(과거의 기억) after "remember".

features.contrast: remember V-ing vs remember to V

stem: Choose the correct form: We went ___ in the river.
rationale: "Go + V-ing" is used for activities(활동 표현).

stem: Choose the correct form: He suggested ___ by bus.
rationale: "Suggest" takes a gerund(동명사), not an infinitive(부정사).

stem: Choose the correct form: I don't mind ___ late.
Choose the correct form: She denied ___ the money.
rationale: "Deny" takes a gerund(동명사) as its object(목적어).

stem: Choose the correct word: ___ other cultures helps us grow.
rationale: A gerund(동명사) can function as a subject(주어).

stem: Choose the correct form: My hobby is ___ stamps.
rationale: After a linking verb(연결동사) like "be", a gerund(동명사) can be a complement(보어).

stem: Choose the correct form: I prefer ___ at home to going out.
rationale: "Prefer doing A to doing B" uses a gerund(동명사) pattern(구문).

features.pattern: prefer V-ing A to V-ing B

stem: Choose the correct form: He admitted ___ the data.
rationale: Use a perfect gerund(완료 동명사) "having + p.p." to show prior action(선행 동작).

stem: Choose the correct form: She is proud of ___ the award.
rationale: After a preposition(전치사) like "of", use a gerund(동명사).

stem: Choose the correct form: I object to his ___ the report late.
rationale: "Object to" takes a gerund(동명사); possessive + gerund(소유격+동명사) is formal and precise.

stem: Choose the correct word: The ___ cat is sleeping.
rationale: Use a present participle(현재분사) as an adjective(형용사 용법).

stem: Choose the correct word: We saw a ___ balloon.
rationale: Present participle(현재분사) can modify a noun(명사 수식).

stem: Choose the correct word: The ___ window was fixed.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) as adjective shows a result state(결과 상태).

stem: Choose the correct word: The car ___ outside is mine.
rationale: A past participle(과거분사) can reduce a relative clause(축약 관계절).

stem: Choose the correct word: A girl ___ a book sat next to me.
rationale: Present participle(현재분사) modifies the noun in a reduced relative clause(축약 관계절).

stem: Choose the correct word: The water ___ on the stove is hot.
rationale: Present participle(현재분사) as a postmodifier(후치 수식).

stem: Choose the correct form: ___ the bus, he read a book.
rationale: A participial clause(분사구문) with V-ing shows time/background(시간/배경).

stem: Choose the correct form: ___ late, she skipped breakfast.
rationale: "Being + adjective" as a participial clause(분사구문) shows reason(이유).

stem: Choose the correct word: ___ by the noise, the baby woke up.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) phrase shows a passive cause(수동적 원인).

stem: Choose the correct form: ___ all the tasks, he went home.
rationale: Perfect participle(완료분사) "having + p.p." shows prior completion(선행 완료).

stem: Choose the correct word: The movie ___ in 1994 won awards.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) reduces a relative clause(축약 관계절).

stem: Choose the correct form: ___ no umbrella, we stayed inside.
rationale: "Having + noun" as a participial clause(분사구문) gives reason(이유).

stem: Choose the correct word: Books ___ in 2020 are on sale.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) works as a reduced relative(축약 관계절).

stem: Choose the best phrase: ___ from a hill, the town looks small.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) phrase shows a passive viewpoint(수동 관점).

stem: Choose the correct sentence:
options: Walking down the street, I saw a cat.
Walking down the street, the cat looked at me.
Walking down the street, was a cat.
Walking down the street, there was a cat.
answer: Walking down the street, I saw a cat.
rationale: The subject(주어) of the participial clause(분사구문) must match the main subject(주어 일치) to avoid a dangling modifier(매달린 수식어).

stem: Choose the correct word: The student ___ the door open was scolded.
rationale: Present participle(현재분사) reduces a relative clause(축약 관계절).

stem: Choose the best phrase: ___ the rules, you must leave.
rationale: Perfect participle(완료분사) shows a completed prior action(선행 완료).

stem: Choose the best word: ___ more time, we could finish.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) in an absolute construction(독립분사구문) sets a condition(조건).

stem: Choose the correct word: ___ by his parents, he felt confident.
rationale: Past participle(과거분사) phrase shows passive cause(수동적 원인).

stem: Choose the correct form: ___ the contract, the CEO left the room.
rationale: Perfect participle(완료분사) highlights a prior completed action(선행 완료) before the main clause.

stem: Choose the correct sentence.
options: Tom is as tall as Ben.
Tom is so tall as Ben.
Tom is the tall as Ben.
answer: Tom is as tall as Ben.

stem: Choose the correct comparative.
options: My bag is lighter than yours.
My bag is lightest than yours.
My bag is more light than yours.
My bag is light than yours.
answer: My bag is lighter than yours.

stem: Of the three boxes, the red one is the ____.
rationale: Superlatives with three or more take -est.

stem: Anna is ____ than Bob.
Choose the correct sentence.
options: This book is better than that one.
This book is more good than that one.
This book is best than that one.
This book is the better than that one.
answer: This book is better than that one.

stem: She runs ____ than her brother.
rationale: Adverb from fast uses -er for comparison.

stem: This road is not ____ that one.
rationale: Negative equative uses not as ... as.

stem: The test was _____ than I expected.
rationale: Comparative form fits the given than‑clause.

stem: There are ____ students this year than last year.
Complete the correlative: The ____ you practice, the ____ you get.
The weather is getting ____ and ____.
rationale: Double comparative repeats the comparative form.

stem: He spoke ____ than usual.
rationale: Adverb with -ly uses more for comparison.

stem: Which sentence compares parallel items correctly?
options: Her salary is higher than her coworkers' salaries.
Her salary is higher than her coworkers.
Her salary is higher than she works.
Her salary is higher than working.
answer: Her salary is higher than her coworkers' salaries.
rationale: Items compared must match in form and meaning.

stem: This year's model is ____ faster than last year's.
rationale: Degree modifiers like much modify comparatives.

stem: He is one of ____ players on the team.
rationale: Use 'one of the + superlative + plural noun'.

stem: Choose the acceptable sentence.
options: This route is preferable to that one.
This route is more preferable than that one.
This route is most preferable than that one.
This route is preferable than that one.
answer: This route is preferable to that one.
rationale: Preferable takes 'to' and does not need a comparative marker.

stem: No sooner had we started ____ it began to rain.
This design is superior ____ the old one.
She is taller than ____.
rationale: Ellipsis of 'I am' favors subject case in formal English.

stem: Choose the correct form: Of the two plans, ____ is better.
rationale: With two items use the comparative, not the superlative.

stem: Choose the article: ___ apple.
I have ___ dog.
rationale: Use a before singular count nouns starting with consonant sounds.

stem: Choose the correct sentence.
We have ____ dinner at six.
I like ____ shoes over there.
rationale: Use those for plural things far away.

stem: Is this ____ notebook?
Do you have ____ questions?
rationale: Use any in questions and negatives.

stem: There isn't ____ sugar left.
rationale: Much is used with uncountable nouns in negatives.

stem: ____ student has a locker.
rationale: Every + singular noun for general statements.

stem: You can take ____ bus. They both go downtown.
rationale: Either means one or the other of two.

stem: We have ____ time, so hurry.
He didn't have ____ money to pay.
rationale: Enough precedes nouns to show sufficiency.

stem: Report the speech: He said, 'I am hungry.'
options: He said that he was hungry.
He said that he is hungry.
He says that he was hungry.
He told that he was hungry.
answer: He said that he was hungry.
rationale: Backshift(시제 이동) present→past in reported statement(간접화법 진술).

stem: Report the speech: She said, 'I like cats.'
options: She said that she liked cats.
She told that she liked cats.
She said that she likes cats.
answer: She said that she liked cats.
rationale: Use "said (that) + clause"(said+that 구조) and backshift(시제 이동).

stem: Report the speech: He said, 'I can swim.'
rationale: Modal backshift(조동사 시제 이동) can→could in reported speech(간접화법).

stem: Report the command: He said to me, 'Open the door.'

stem: Report the negative command: She said to me, 'Don't touch it.'

rationale: Use "told + O + not to V" for negative imperative(부정 명령 간접화법).

stem: Report the question: He asked, 'Are you ready?'

stem: Report the question: She asked, 'Where do you live?'

stem: Report the speech: He said, 'I have finished.'
Report the speech: She said, 'I will go tomorrow.'
options: She said she would go the next day.
She said she will go tomorrow.
She told she would go tomorrow.
She said that she go next day.
answer: She said she would go the next day.

stem: Report the speech: He said, 'We are here now.'
options: He said they were there then.
He said we were here then.

He told they were there now.
answer: He said they were there then.
rationale: Pronoun/time/place shift(대명사·시간·장소 전환): we→they, here→there, now→then.

stem: Report the speech: He said, 'I saw her yesterday.'

He said he saw her yesterday.
He told he had seen her yesterday.
He said he has seen her the day before.
answer: He said he had seen her the day before.
rationale: Past→past perfect with time shift yesterday→the day before(시제·시간 전환).

stem: Report the speech: She said, 'I must leave.'

She said she must to leave.

stem: Choose the verb: He ___ me that he was busy.

stem: Choose the verb: The teacher said that water ___ at 100°C.

stem: Report the speech: He said, 'I was reading.'

stem: Report the speech: She said, 'I may be late.'

She said she may be late.

answer: She said she might be late.

stem: Report the suggestion: He said, 'Let's start now.'

rationale: "Eldest" is preferred for family order(가족 서열 최상급).

stem: Choose the correct unit: a ___ of bread
rationale: Measure word(양화사) for bread is "loaf"(빵 한 덩이).

stem: Choose the correct form: ___ hundred people attended.
rationale: No plural -s on "hundred" after numerals(수사 뒤 hundred 단수형).

stem: Choose the correct word: one and a half ___
rationale: After "one and a half" use plural(복수형).

stem: Choose the correct phrase: ___ of the students has a laptop.
rationale: "Each of + plural N + singular verb"(Each of + 복수명사 + 단수동사).

stem: Choose the correct phrase: ___ percent of the class is absent.
rationale: Use "percent" with a numeral(수사+percent); verb agrees with the of‑phrase head(동사 일치).

stem: Choose the best phrase: The company hired ___ 50 engineers.
rationale: Traditional rule: "fewer" with countables(가산명사), "less" with uncountables(불가산명사).

stem: 지문: 그는 넥타이를 고쳐 매고 이력서를 확인한 뒤 두 명의 면접관 맞은편에 앉았다. 질문: 상황에 대한 추론으로 가장 적절한 것은?

Text: Tom has a dog. He walks it every day.
Question: Who does "He" refer to?
rationale: Pronoun reference(대명사 지칭) resolves "He" to the human subject Tom(선행사).

stem:
Text: Mina found a coin. She put it in her pocket.
Question: What does "it" refer to?
rationale: Object pronoun(목적격 대명사) "it" refers to the most recent suitable noun(가장 가까운 적절한 명사) "coin".

stem:
Text: The cat chased the mouse, and it hid under the sofa.
Question: What does "it" refer to?
rationale: Semantic fit(의미 적합성): hider is likely the mouse, not the cat(의미 기반 지칭).

stem:
Text: Jisu called her mom because she was worried.
Question: Who was worried?
rationale: Cause–result heuristic(원인-결과 추론): caller is typically the worried one(전형성에 근거한 지칭).

stem:
Text: Dad gave Ben a toy. He thanked him.
Question: Who thanked whom?
rationale: Role consistency(논항 역할 일치): recipient(수령자) → "he"; giver(주는 사람) → "him".

stem:
Text: I met Hana near the station. That made me happy.
Question: What does "That" refer to?
rationale: Demonstrative anaphora(지시사 대용): "That" points to the previous event(이전 사건 지시).

stem:
Text: The teacher told the students to be quiet. They listened at once.

rationale: Plural agreement(수 일치) links "They" to "students"(복수 선행사).

stem:
Text: Jaeho lost his key. This worried him all morning.
Question: What does "This" refer to?
rationale: Sentence-initial "This"(초두 지시사) summarizes the prior clause(앞문장 요약 지시).

stem:
Text: The bird sat on the branch. It was thin and shaky.

rationale: Adjective compatibility(형용사 적합성): "thin and shaky" fits "branch" better(의미 적합).

stem:
Text: When Minsu met Eric, he bowed first.

rationale: Subject preference(주어 선호) and cultural schema(문화 스키마) support "Minsu"(지칭 규칙).

stem:
Text: Sora lent Nayeon her umbrella because it was raining.

rationale: Non-restrictive relative(비한정 관계사) "which" can refer to a whole proposition(문장 전체 지시).

answer: Although the road was icy, we reached the village safely.

stem: Combine with a semicolon and 'however'.
inputs: The effect was consistent across groups.
answer: The study was small; however, the effect was consistent across groups.
rationale: Link independent clauses with contrastive adverb.

stem: Combine using a defining relative clause ('where').
answer: I know a cafe where they bake great bread.

stem: Combine by reducing the relative clause.
inputs: The data that were collected in May show a decline.
answer: The data collected in May show a decline.
rationale: Omit 'that were' in passive relative clauses.

stem: Combine using a conditional inversion ('Had …, …').
answer: Had I seen your email, I would have replied sooner.

stem: Combine using a noun clause with 'that'.
inputs: The committee concluded the policy was effective.
answer: The committee concluded that the policy was effective after reviewing the evidence.
rationale: Embed conclusion as a 'that'‑clause and add adjunct.

Please direct the transportation committee to pilot two blocks this summer and publish results.
Sincerely,
Daniel Yoo
rationale: Claims, evidence, feasible steps, and action request.

Science rises before lab days; add 30 minutes for review. History is lowest at 1 hour; pair it with daily 10‑minute flashcards. Total time increases by about 2 hours.

stem: Write 120–140 words analyzing quarterly revenue by product.

C climbs from 60 to 85 with a small Q3 pause. The portfolio ends with record Q4 revenue driven by A’s consistency and B’s rebound. The mix is shifting modestly toward A and B.

stem: Write 120–140 words summarizing survey results (5‑point scale).
answer: Responses are positive overall. For “Schedule is clear,” 75% selected Agree or Strongly Agree (40% and 35%), with few negatives. “Materials are useful” skews slightly lower but still has 68% positive. “Would recommend” reaches 65% positive with a small negative tail. Priorities: clarify materials and raise the recommend score by improving onboarding and examples.
rationale: Converts counts into shares and sets priorities.

stem: Write 120–140 words comparing mode share of commuting.

To reduce congestion, the largest gains likely come from moving short car trips to transit, walk, and bike. A policy mix of more frequent buses and protected bike lanes targets the 25–35% of trips within 5 km.
rationale: States ranking and links to actionable levers.

stem: Write 130–150 words analyzing energy generation by source across two years (percent).

Nuclear ticked up to 19%. The system is diversifying, with the largest shift coming from coal to wind and solar. Continuing this path likely depends on grid upgrades to handle variable output.
rationale: Quantifies shifts and names the main substitution.

stem: Write 130–150 words comparing A/B test conversion rates.

If traffic quality was similar, B appears better. Next steps: confirm with a longer run or a second test and check impacts on downstream metrics such as retention.
rationale: Computes rates and suggests validation steps.

stem: Write 130–150 words summarizing monthly electricity use (kWh) and recommend one action.
answer: Usage declines from 520 kWh in January to a low of 430 in April, then ticks up to 470 in May. The four‑month drop suggests heating demand eased, while the May rise may reflect more cooling or equipment changes. One practical action is to set a 24°C cooling target and seal window gaps before summer; similar households cut May–August use by 5–10% with that change.
rationale: Describes trend and gives a specific, low‑cost recommendation.

stem: Evidence: "Students who attend tutoring improve by 10%." Warrant (전제/연결 논리) that connects to claim "Offer free tutoring."

stem: To support "longer lunch improves nutrition," which study design (연구 설계) is stronger?

stem: Study: schools with longer recess have higher scores. Which control (통제변수) helps address confounding (혼입)?

stem: To strengthen a causal claim (인과 주장) that "daily reading raises vocabulary," choose the strongest evidence.

rationale: Randomized controlled trial(무작위 대조 실험) best supports causation(인과).
